the "hot water freezes faster than cold" effect is whats known in science as "bullshit". no one has been able to reproduce this, there is exactly one paper supposedly "demonstrating" that it happens, and it has so many unknown variables and so many experimental flaws that i would hesitate to call it scientific (its not even about water, its about ice cream mix, where sugar and other substances can interfere with the formation of ice crystals). all subsequent studies (done with plain water) either showed no such effect or are just (very wanky) conjectures about what "might" be happening.

its really not that complicated: for hot water to freeze, at some point it will have to pass through "room" temperature. meaning that, from that point onwards, it will take as long to freeze as an equal amount of room temperature water. plus the time it took to reach that point. thats just a result of continuous functions.

now, tap water that has been boiled might freeze faster than tap water that hasnt, but that is something completely different (i.e., those are effectively two different substances, not the same substance at two temperatures).done with distilled water, under controlled conditions, it simply does not happen.

I didn't know the Mpemba effect had a name. I just chocked the thing up to being "Theory of acceleration".
Basically, hot water is constantly "driving" towards being cold. If you incorporate a freezing temperature, it starts speeding wildly down that road with a high speed & acceleration. At the point where it reaches the same temperature as the cold water, it doesn't stop very easily, so it reaches freezing temperature super quickly.
Since the cold water started, it was already cold & was basically cruising. It's acceleration & top-speed were very low; in fact, it starts out in reverse, because it was in warmer air, so it needed time to get in gear & start down it's path.

There's also the fact that hot things tend to do stuff more quickly, much the same as cartoon 'man-on-fire' & 'man-in-ice-block'
Not only that, but hot water is constantly circulating, so warmer water is touching the sides of the freezing glass.

I have a quick explanation of the The Mpemba Effect which isn't complex at all but not quite convection: it is caused by the entropy of the water being in a collectively higher energy state. 

Using that basis and the fact that molecules are more agitated and physically move more during high entropy, the more the molecules interact with each other and the faster the individual molecules can share/lose their energy/entropy and therefore heat. 

This is why, warmer water in a higher entropy/energy state freezes and looses its heat/entropy faster than water which is colder and in a lower entropy state. 
AKA more entropy = faster enthalpy change because molecules share and lose their energy faster creating this effect

When hydrogen and oxygen react for a exothermic reaction.
When a particular reaction is exothermic, the reverse reaction is always endothermic. This means that decomposition of water by any means (Electrolysis or combustion) must be an endothermic reaction. However, all combustion reactions are exothermic in nature as combustion releases heat.

The simple reason why water is inflammable is because its decomposition REQUIRES a lot of energy, which is not possible in case of combustion.
